name: 英語詞源學
goals: To become familiar with the word analysis method
To gain a new perspective on English language and etymology
To reflect on the major social and cultural developments in the  history of the English language
To uncover the hidden and often surprising connection between word connections
To associate new words with less familiar ones
To present valuable, up-to-date information on new words and coinages
syllabus:
**Course description**

This course is about the origins and structure of English words. It surveys the historical events in the development of the English language and explores the linguistic changes accompanying word formation. In addition, students will expand their vocabulary by studying classical roots. 

**Required text**

A reader compiled by the instructor

**Course requirements**

Midterm (30%), Final (35%)

Written reports (20%)

Class participation, incl. presentations (15%)

**Course Schedule (16 +2)**

Week 1: Course overview and preliminaries

Week 2: Linguistic ancestry | Roots set

Week 3: No class (holiday)

Week 4 & 5: Historical developments | Roots set | Lit review: Faure

Week 6 & 7: Word analyzability | Roots set | Lit review: Gold/Sarma, Jozwiak, Bielenia-Grajewska

Week 8: No class (holiday) \*MK1: Mini-corpus of word usage

Week 9: Midterm

Week 10: Recent loans | Roots set | Lit review: Kay, Ali Jassem, McCafferty

Week 11 & 12: Semantic change | Roots set | Lit review: Haugen, Faure

Week 13 & 14: Replacement rules | Roots set | Lit review: Murray, Castillo

Week 15: Roots set | Lit review: McCafferty, Al-Kadi, Androutsopoulos

Week 16: Final

\*Flexible sessions (online): Selected articles + Moodle assignment
prerequisite: ◎Unavailable for M.A. program students (M.A. program courses excepted) and B.A. program students.
